title: Cities of Refuge
shortSummary: Joshua 20 details God's command to Joshua to designate cities of refuge for those who commit unintentional manslaughter. These cities provide protection from the avenger of blood until a fair trial can be held, demonstrating God's justice and mercy in the community. This chapter underscores the importance of law, order, and grace within Israel's covenantal society.
timeline: c. 1406 BC - Conquest of Canaan under Joshua

keyCharacters.name: Joshua
keyCharacters.description: The leader of Israel who receives God's instructions to designate cities of refuge and implements this divine ordinance.

keyCharacters.name: The Elders of the City
keyCharacters.description: Local leaders who hear the cause of the slayer and provide him refuge within the city.

keyCharacters.name: The Avenger of Blood
keyCharacters.description: A family member who seeks to avenge the death of a relative, from whom the slayer is protected if the killing was unintentional.

keyCharacters.name: The High Priest
keyCharacters.description: The religious leader whose death marks the end of the slayer’s refuge period, allowing him to return home safely.

definitions.definition: A designated city where one who has killed another unintentionally can flee to avoid revenge until a fair trial is held.
A relative of a deceased person who is responsible for seeking justice or revenge against the killer.
Without intention or knowledge; accidentally or unintentionally.
The assembly or community of Israelite leaders who judge legal matters.

outline.heading: God’s Command to Establish Cities of Refuge
outline.description: God instructs Joshua to designate specific cities as places of refuge for those who kill unintentionally, ensuring protection from the avenger of blood.

outline.heading: Procedure for the Slayer Seeking Refuge
outline.description: The slayer must present himself at the city gate and declare his case to the elders, who then provide him shelter, protecting him from vengeance.

outline.heading: Duration of Refuge and Return Home
outline.description: The slayer remains in the city of refuge until standing trial before the congregation and until the death of the high priest, after which he may safely return home.

outline.heading: Designation of the Six Cities of Refuge
outline.description: Joshua appoints six cities—three on each side of the Jordan River—to serve as cities of refuge, fulfilling God's command.

outline.heading: Purpose and Inclusiveness of the Cities
outline.description: These cities serve all Israelites and sojourners, providing a just system of protection for anyone who kills unintentionally.

application: Trust in God's provision of justice and mercy, knowing He provides protection even for those who err unintentionally.
Practice patience and fairness in judgment, following biblical principles when dealing with conflicts or accusations.
Recognize the importance of community accountability and the role of spiritual leaders in guiding justice.
Live with integrity to avoid causing harm to others, but also extend grace to those who repent and seek refuge.

keyVerses.text: That the slayer that killeth any person unawares and unwittingly may flee thither: and they shall be your refuge from the avenger of blood.
keyVerses.significance: This verse highlights God's provision of mercy and protection for those who sin unintentionally, emphasizing His justice balanced with grace.

keyVerses.text: And he shall dwell in that city, until he stand before the congregation for judgment, and until the death of the high priest that shall be in those days: then shall the slayer return, and come unto his own city, and unto his own house, unto the city from whence he fled.
keyVerses.significance: This verse explains the conditions for the slayer’s release, showing the importance of due process and the high priest’s role in Israel’s legal system.

keyVerses.text: These were the cities appointed for all the children of Israel, and for the stranger that sojourneth among them, that whosoever killeth any person at unawares might flee thither, and not die by the hand of the avenger of blood, until he stood before the congregation.
keyVerses.significance: This verse underscores the inclusiveness of God's law, extending protection to both Israelites and foreigners living among them.
